results.title: Melbourne (no. 8)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Shot of Yarra, looking towards Anderson St bridge.

Section 2. Royal Melbourne Show. Shots of various farm machinery on display. Crowds of people walking around enjoying themselves. Wood-chopping competition. Ladies riding horses, horse racing. More wood-chopping.

results.title: Melbourne (no. 4)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Several shots of daffodils in a park. Nice colour, long shots.

Section 2. Shots in a park near the Yarra looking towards the city.

Section 3. Shots of Fitzroy gardens, conservatory and Government House.

Section 4. Shots of large houses in Toorak.

Section 5. ANZAC day march in the city. Many people involved.

results.title: Melbourne (no. 2)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Football match between Carlton and Richmond at Punt Road oval. Huge crowd. Good shots of football being played and the crowd reacting to the game.

Section 2. Two women at an observation point above the city.

Section 3. Shot of State Library with tram going past, shot of two statues in the city.

Section 4. Shots taken from behind St Paul’s cathederal looking down towards the Yarra, MCG and Flinders St train tracks.

Section 5. Shots of various statues and fountains around Melbourne.

Section 6. Shot from car driving along St Kilda Road, away from the city.

Section 7. Shots of city in the afternoon. Busy scene with Cars, buses, trams and people.

Section 8. Shot looking towards city from bank of Yarra. A man sits on a park bench in the foreground, surrounded by Seagulls.

results.title: Melbourne (no. 3)
results.brief_description: Film features quite general shots of Melbourne in the summer. This includes footage of the Great Ocean Road (including panoramas), a busy suburban pool and St. Kilda Beach. These sequences have a great, nostalgic ‘good time’ vibe to them, which is aided in part by the high-contrast film stock. There is also footage of one of Melbourne’s Gardens (possibly the Botanic), including blooming flowers and people looking at them. Nice shots of man burning leaves followed by the sun breaking through smoke haze and trees in garden. Two shots include views of St. Paul’s Cathederal and the Forum Theatre from the Yarra. Nice, Black and White ‘The End’.

results.title: Pentuphouse
results.brief_description: An aging jazz singer (played with poignant resolve by Gillian Jones) must contend with her highly strung, drug using boyfriend. Director Cate Shortland traces with assured confidence the complex and delicate nuances of aging and compromise within a self destructive relationship.

results.title: Melbourne (no. 1)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Brief shots of the Shrine of Rememberance.

Section 2. Shots of the 1848 building from several angles.

Section 3. A cricket match at the MCG. Sparse crowd. Several angles and shots, lasts for three minutes.

Section 4. Luna Park at night. Brief shot of the entrance and the exterior of a dogem cars attraction.

Section 5. Houses in Melbourne; older and ‘new’. Brief.

Section 6. Various shots of parks and gardens. Brief.

Section 7. Spencer Street rail yards, shot from above. Brief.

Section 8. A few shots of the city, including trams and St. Paul’s cathederal.

Section 9. Woman in a park, admiring a flower bed. Good close-ups.

Section 10. Camera pans up from the Yarra to St Paul’s Cathederal/city in the distance. Nice shot.

Section 11. Good shots of the city from the Yarra.

results.title: Grace
results.brief_description: Returning from her adopted home in London, to attend the funeral of her sister, an Aboriginal woman finds herself isolated from both kin and culture. This emotionally mature and complex work moves beyond didactism and easily digestable polemics to suggest that cultural dislocation is written as much in the body, in language and the psyche as it is in economics and politics. By suggesting that the effects for the “stolen generation” were as destructive for inter-Aboriginal relationships as they were for black and white relations in this country, “Grace” is a devastating and confronting exploration of what it means to have been “stolen”.
results.description: Returning from her adopted home in London, to attend the funeral of her sister, an Aboriginal woman finds herself isolated from both kin and culture. This emotionally mature and complex work moves beyond didactism and easily digestable polemics to suggest that cultural dislocation is written as much in the body, in language and the psyche as it is in economics and politics. By suggesting that the effects for the “stolen generation” were as destructive for inter-Aboriginal relationships as they were for black and white relations in this country, “Grace” is a devastating and confronting exploration of what it means to have been “stolen”.

This emotionally mature and complex work moves beyond didactism and easily digestable polemics to suggest that cultural dislocation is written as much in the body, in language and the psyche as it is in economics and politics. By suggesting that the effects for the “stolen generation” were as destructive for inter-Aboriginal relationships as they were for black and white relations in this country, “Grace” is a devastating and confronting exploration of what it means to have been “stolen”.

results.title: Spotlights: Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama. Her films often feature female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors and also mentions My Brilliant Career (1979), which features in the New Wave section of Moving Australia.

constellations_primary.name: Brilliant careers (Gillian Armstrong)
constellations_primary.description: Gillian Armstrong's feature film debut not only helped launch her own acclaimed career, but those of the actors as well.

results.description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama, Gillian Armstrong’s work often features female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors as well as her groundbreaking debut My Brilliant Career (1979).
description_for_label: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama, Gillian Armstrong’s work often features female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors as well as her groundbreaking debut My Brilliant Career (1979).

results.title: Spotlights: Eric Bana
results.brief_description: Eric Banadinović AM, known professionally as Eric Bana, is an Australian actor. He began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997) before gaining critical acclaim as the lead in Chopper (2000).

constellations_primary.name: Eric Bana
constellations_primary.description: There must be something that draws Australian creatives like Eric Bana to darker material as they shoot to stardom overseas. Australia's penal colony past perhaps?

results.description: Eric Bana is an Australian actor who began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997). Soon after he gained critical recognition in the biographical crime film Chopper (2000). Eric discusses the influence of the car on the Australian psyche.
description_for_label: Eric Bana is an Australian actor who began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997).
